content:
• Wednesday, May 20, 2015
  • YOKU

    Youku Tudou up late after revenue beat, upside Q2 guidance

    • China's net-TV leader Youku Tudou (NYSE:YOKU) was selling off after hours before reversing course, +1.4%, after it posted a mixed Q1 earnings report where a net loss widened despite revenues that grew 51% and beat expectations easily.
    • The company recorded a gross loss in non-GAAP terms of $5.3M, vs. a year-ago gross profit of $14.6M, as its content costs jumped 87.6%, to 669M yuan ($107.9M). Content costs were 59% of net revenues, up from 46%, and bandwidth costs of $49.5M were 29% of revenues.
    • Chairman and CEO Victor Koo says strategy will improve business economics: Q1 was "marked by solid progress in the three key growth pillars that drive our business development for this year: accelerated topline growth, revenue diversification, and significant ramp up of web-native content."
    • The company guided to Q2 revenues of 1.47B-1.52B yuan ($237M-$245M, on the high side of an expected $225.5M). It expects advertising revenues to be between 1.25B-1.3B yuan.
    • Conference call at 9 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:30 PM
  • CVS

    Bloomberg: CVS in advanced talks to buy Omnicare

    • CVS is in advanced talks to buy nursing home pharmacy owner Omnicare (NYSE:OCR) and could reach a deal as soon as this week, sources tell Bloomberg.
    • Omnicare hired advisors to find a buyer earlier this year. In April, Bloomberg reported CVS was one of several interested parties.
    • OCR +5.7% AH to $100.00. CVS +0.5% to $101.80.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:15 PM | 5 Comments
  • WAVX

    Wave plans stock/warrant offering; shares -8.5%

    • Wave Systems (NASDAQ:WAVX) plans a new stock/warrant offering of yet-undetermined size. Net proceeds will be used for working capital.
    • The encryption/authentication software firm had $3.2M in cash at the end of Q1. A 5.5M-share stock/warrant offering yielding net proceeds of $3.3M was carried out in January.
    • Shares have fallen to $0.75 AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:45 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers: COVS +3.5%. ANY +2.9%. PLNR +1.9%. ZNGA +1.3%. UTHR +1.2%.
    • Top losers: BRKR -4.5%. SGEN -4.1%. PBMD -3.2%. EARS -2.9%. MRD -2.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:41 PM | 3 Comments
  • CTP

    CTPartners in exclusive negotiations to be acquired by DHR International

    • CTPartners Executive Search (NYSEMKT:CTP) +42% AH after agreeing to exclusive negotiations to be acquired by DHR International.
    • Pricing and other terms have not been disclosed, but the indicated preliminary price range set forth in the indication of interest is below the $7/share DHR previously proposed to pay in a February letter to the CTP board.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM
  • CRM

    Salesforce +4.7% on results/guidance; free cash flow rises 60%

    • Salesforce's (NYSE:CRM) deferred revenue balance rose 31% Y/Y in FQ1 to $3.06B, nearly even with FQ4's 32%; mid-to-high 20s growth is expected in FQ2. The unbilled deferred revenue balance rose 25% to $6B; FQ4 growth was 27%.
    • Thanks in part to the deferred revenue growth, free cash flow (GAAP net cash - capex) rose 60% Y/Y to $659.8M, far above non-GAAP net income of $108.3M. Capex totaled $71.1M (5% of revenue).
    • Business performance: Sales Cloud subscription/support revenue +9% Y/Y to $630.4M; Service Cloud (customer support software) +38% to $407.7M; Marketing Cloud (ExactTarget) +29% to $143.2M; Salesforce1 platform/other (Heroku/Force.com) +36% to $224M. Professional services/other revenue +33% to $106M.
    • Regional performance: Americas revenue (74% of total) +27% Y/Y to $1.11B. Europe +12% to $258.8M; Asia-Pac +15% to $137.2M. A strong dollar had a 4% impact on total revenue growth, and 16% and 12% impacts on Europe and Asia-Pac growth.
    • Financials: Operating expenses (non-GAAP) rose 15% Y/Y to $987.7M, trailing revenue growth of 23%. On a GAAP basis, sales/marketing spend totaled $737M, R&D $222M, and G&A $176M. Salesforce ended FQ1 with $1.92B in cash/marketable securities, and $1.3B in debt.
    • Shares have risen to $73.48 AH.
    • Salesforce's results/guidance, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:10 PM | 12 Comments
  • XNET

    Xunlei -18% after revenue miss, downside guidance

    • Digital media platform Xunlei (NASDAQ:XNET) has cratered after hours, -18%, following a Q1 earnings report where it significantly missed revenue expectations and issued downside guidance for Q2.
    • Shares had risen 7.1% today ahead of the report.
    • Xunlei entered an agreement with Beijing Nesound to sell its entire stake in video-streaming platform Xunlei Kankan for 130M yuan (about $21M), and excluded it from its tables.
    • Revenues of $30.2M were down more than 8% Y/Y and missed an expected $40M. Subscription revenues of $21.2M were down 14.7%.
    • The company says its Q2 revenue should be $25M-$29M, vs. an expectation of $43.6M (one analyst).
    • Conference call tomorrow at 8 a.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:07 PM
  • OTEX

    OpenText -7.2%; CEO returns, job cuts launched, soft guidance issued

    • After cutting his day-to-day involvement with the company earlier this year as he underwent treatment for leukemia, OpenText (NASDAQ:OTEX) CEO Mark Barrenechea has "resumed full involvement in day-to-day operations."
    • The content management software vendor has also announced a restructuring expected to cut its headcount by 5%. $50M/year in cost savings and a $25M restructuring charge are expected.
    • As part of the restructuring, sales chief Jon Hunter has left the company. Several other sales/customer service execs have been promoted.
    • Likely contributing to Hunter's departure: OpenText expects FQ4 revenue of $440M-$455M and EPS of $0.64-$0.72, below a consensus of $487.8M and $0.89. A strong dollar is expected to have a $0.11 impact on EPS; OpenText also states its ongoing shift towards cloud software sales (pushes out revenue recognition) and "a challenging global selling environment" took a toll.
    • The company plans to "grow our Cloud business through acquisitions, innovation and with new ways to purchase our solutions."
    • Shares have fallen to $45.46 AH on account of the guidance.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:40 PM
  • EGHT

    Comms firm 8x8 up 3.3% after beating on top, bottom lines

    • Software comms firm 8x8 (NASDAQ:EGHT) is up 3.3% after hours, regaining some of today's 1.1% decline after wrapping its fiscal year with a beat on top and bottom lines.
    • Average monthly service revenue/business customer was up 11% to $320, and business service revenue churn was 0.5%, down from the prior year's 1.2%. The company ended FQ4 with 41,621 business customers (up 10%).
    • Cash, equivalents and investments were at $177.1M, near flat Y/Y.
    • For fiscal 2016, the company's guiding to revenue of $193M-$197M vs. expected $212.7M, and non-GAAP net income at 6%-9% of revenue (which would make $11.6M-$17.7M).
    • Conference call starting now, 4:30 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM | 3 Comments
  • NTAP

    NetApp -6.5% on FQ4 miss, weak guidance; dividend hiked by 9%

    • NetApp (NASDAQ:NTAP) has fallen to $33.02 AH after missing FQ4 estimates and guiding for FQ1 revenue of $1.275B-$1.375B and EPS of $0.20-$0.25, well below a consensus of $1.46B and $0.60.
    • Along with the numbers, NetApp announces it's hiking its quarterly dividend by 9% to $0.18/share - that spells a 2.2% yield at AH levels. The next dividend will be paid on July 23 to shareholders on record as of the July 10 close.
    • CEO Tom Georgens: "We are not satisfied with our fourth quarter results and are taking concrete action to transition NetApp for the next phase of growth." Several analysts had issued cautious notes ahead of earnings, while often mentioning competition from flash/hybrid storage upstarts, cloud storage providers, and/or EMC.
    • Business performance: FQ4 product revenue -12% Y/Y to $913.4M; software maintenance (steadier) down fractionally to $226.5M; hardware maintenance/other services +6% to $399.8M. Branded revenue -7% to $1.44B; OEM revenue (hurt by declining IBM revenue) -18% to $101.7M.
    • Financials: Gross margin fell 260 bps Q/Q and 240 bps Y/Y to 62%. Operating expenses fell by $2.2M Y/Y (less than 1%) to $715M. $246.3M was spent on buybacks. NetApp ended FQ4 with $5.33B in cash/investments, and $1.49B in long-term debt.
    • FQ4 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:26 PM
  • WSM

    All brands clicking for Williams-Sonoma in Q1

    • Williams-Sonoma (NYSE:WSM) reports total comparable brand sales were up 4.6% in Q1.
    • Comp growth by brand: Pottery Barn +2.4%, Williams Sonoma +2.7%, Pottery Barn Kids +0.8%, PBteen +3.0%, West Elm +15.3%.
    • E-commerce sales +8.4% to $533M.
    • Operating margin -60 bps to 7.0%.
    • SG&A expense rate -40 bps to 29.8%.
    • Merchandise inventory +10.9% to $943M.
    • Previously: Williams-Sonoma beats by $0.03, beats on revenue
    • WSM +4.6% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM
  • CRM

    Salesforce beats estimates, issues solid guidance; shares rise

    • Salesforce.com (NYSE:CRM): FQ1 EPS of $0.16 beats by $0.02.
    • Revenue of $1.51B (+22.8% Y/Y) beats by $10M.
    • Expects FQ2 revenue of $1.59B-$1.6B (+21% Y/Y) and EPS of $0.17-$0.18 vs. consensus of $1.59B and $0.17.
    • Expects FY16 (ends Jan. '16) revenue of $6.52B-$6.55B (+21%-22% Y/Y) and EPS of $0.69-$0.71 vs. consensus of $6.51B and $0.69.
    • Shares +3.4% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:10 PM | 28 Comments
  • APO

    Apollo Global higher as Morgan Stanley pulls sell recommendation

    • Morgan Stanley's thesis that cash earnings would decline as Apollo Global (APO +1.5%) neared the end of its harvesting cycle played out in Q1, with the P-E business contributing just $0.13 per share in net realized performance fees (vs. the $1.08 peak in 2013 Q2).
    • With the stock underperforming by 1,900 basis points in 2015, things could be bottoming out, says Morgan, upgrading to Equalweight from Underweight.
    • If the shares were going to go much lower, says Morgan, they would have already done so given management stock sales and the weakest results in nearly three years.
    • "Faster deployment in Fund VIII won't benefit near-term cash earnings, but it could boost or pull forward the start of APO's next harvest and the meaningful inflection point in cash earnings we expect in 2018."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM
  • BTG

    B2Gold secures new $350M credit facility, lifts gold production

    • B2Gold (BTG +5.8%) surges higher after securing a new revolving credit facility and boosting its gold production.
    • The credit agreement totals $350M and allows for an accordion feature where upon receipt of additional binding commitments, the facility may be increased to $450M any time prior to the maturity date.
    • BTG says the new facility will enable it to meet its objective of always maintaining available cash resources of at least $100M on hand through the course of construction and up to the commencement of operations at the Fekola project in Mali.
    • BTG also says the rapid ramp-up of its Otjikoto mine in Namibia has it on track to meet guidance with gold production increasing from 390K oz. in 2014 to 500K-540K oz. in 2015, with projected cash operating costs of $630-$660/oz.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • AIG

    AIG scores 4 1/2-year high

    • AIG is quietly higher by 7.25% YTD, outpacing stocks like MetLife and Prudential, both of which are in the red in 2015, and the XLF which is just barely in the green.
    • The insurer's 1% gain today puts it above $60 per share for the first time since the opening days of 2011. The next stop on the charts would be before the company's collapse in 2008. The all-time split-adjusted high was over $1,400 per share in June 2007.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM | 8 Comments
  • WBAI

    500.com continues soaring post-earnings

    • 500.com (WBAI +10.3%) is now up 44% since posting Q1 results and announcing a CEO change yesterday morning. Shares are at their highest levels since last November.
    • The Chinese online sports lottery vendor used its Q1 CC (transcript) to reiterate its belief the company's license to provide online sports lottery sales "is valid and has not been revoked or amended." It also forecast expenses "will be materially coming down" Y/Y in Q2, a quarter for which no revenue is expected.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM
  • NTES

    NetEase up to 52-week highs, forming finance JV

    • Game maker NetEase (NASDAQ:NTES) is up 3.2%, building onto the last month's price appreciation and making a new 52-week high after announcing it's forming an Internet finance joint venture through its e-commerce unit.
    • Ujia E-commerce, a subsidiary of NetEase, will join with Everbright Securities and HNA Group in a venture with capital of 100M yuan (about $16.1M). Ujia is contributing 30M yuan.
    • The venture is designed to "bring even more robust e-commerce offerings to our growing community of Internet users," says NetEase CEO William Ding.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:50 PM
  • ETSY

    Etsy plunges towards IPO price; Street worried about growth, spending

    • Etsy (ETSY -20.6%) is now less than $0.70 above its $16 April 16 IPO price as the Street shows no mercy in response to Q1 results that included slower-than-expected GMS growth of 28%. Shares are down 47% from a post-IPO opening trade of $31.00.
    • There's "no denying growth is slowing faster than we believe investors expected," says Morgan Stanley's Brian Nowak, one of several analysts to provide cautious reactions. He notes international GMS growth (hurt by a strong dollar) was only 22%, and thinks Etsy's numbers are "likely to put the 'addressable market question' on the front burner."
    • Wedbush's Gil Luria, who downgraded ahead of earnings, is worried about Etsy's plans to up its marketing spend in the face of "diminishing returns." The company plans to advertise listings via Google's popular product listing ads (PLAs) in Q2, as well as launch its first mobile app ad campaign.
    • Brean is defending the craft/vintage goods marketplace. The firm highlights Etsy's 72.3% seller services (ads, payments, shipping) revenue growth, argues core metrics remain healthy, and declares its thesis that "Etsy operates a differentiated marketplace and has multiple levers to pull to drive sustainable long-term sales growth and adjusted EBITDA margin expansion" remains in place.
    • Shares now trade for 9x 2014 sales and (given recent growth) perhaps 7x forward sales.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:30 PM | 6 Comments

  • Treasurys hold gains after FOMC minutes

    • FOMC members lost their taste for a June rate hike between the March and April meetings, as "several" in favor in March, becomes just a "few" six weeks later.
    • Nevertheless, the Committee continues to feel the Q1 growth slowdown was transitory, and thus a rate hike remains on the table for some point this year.
    • The 10-year Treasury yield remains four basis points lower on the session at 2.25%, and 30-day Fed Funds futures are pricing in a 25 basis points move late in Q4.
    • TLT +0.8%, TBT -1.6%
    • ETFs: TBT, TLT, TMV, TBF, EDV, TMF, TTT, ZROZ, TLH, SBND, VGLT, UBT, DLBS, TLO, TENZ, LBND, DLBL, TYBS, VUSTX
     
     
     
     
    | 2:30 PM | 1 Comment
  • WIX

    Wix up 4.3% after CEO's Mad Money appearance

    • Wix.com (NASDAQ:WIX) chairman/CEO Avishai Abrahami appeared on yesterday evening's airing of Jim Cramer's Mad Money. Among other things, Abrahami talked up the value proposition of Wix's site-building tools for SMBs looking to avoid hiring programmers, its efforts to up-sell users on premium subscriptions, and (a Super Bowl ad notwithstanding) its ability to grow via word-of-mouth.
    • Shares have made new 52-week highs, and are up 23% YTD. They jumped two weeks ago in response to the strong guidance provided within Wix's Q1 report.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:05 PM | 1 Comment
  • PXLW

    Pixelworks up 10.6% on strong volume

    • Pixelworks (NASDAQ:PXLW) has surged on volume of 505K shares (far above a 3-month daily average of 188K). No news has yet hit the wires to explain the move.
    • The video processor developer has recovered the losses seen 3 weeks ago after it posted a Q1 miss and issued soft Q2 guidance. Shares go for 1.6x 2015E sales and 1.3x 2016E sales.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:48 PM | 6 Comments
  • APEN

    Lpath's lead product candidate fails Phase 2 study; shares plunge 80%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Lpath (LPTN -79.5%) craters on a massive 78x surge in volume in response to its announcement that its lead product candidate, iSONEP, failed to achieve its primary and key secondary efficacy endpoints in a Phase 2 trial in patients with wet age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD) who had not responded adequately to anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) therapies such as Roche's (OTCQX:RHHBY -0.4%) Lucentis (ranibuzumab) or Avastin (bevacizumab) or Regeneron's (REGN +1.4%) Eylea (aflibercept).
    • Patients treated with iSONEP, either alone or as an adjunct, did not show any statistically significant improvement in visual acuity.
    • SVP and Chief Development Officer Dario Paggiarino, M.D., says, "This trial was designed to evaluate the activity of iSONEP in wet AMD patients that had previously received at least three prior injections of an anti-VEGF agent and had not responded well. While the primary endpoint of the trial was not met, we will be conducting a complete analysis of the data, including additional anatomical endpoints, to better understand the results from each arm of the trial."
    • iSONEP is a monoclonal antibody that binds to a bioactive lipid called sphingosine-1-phosphate, a major regulator of vascular systems.
    • Final results will be presented in November at the American Academy of Ophthalmology meeting in Las Vegas, NV.
    • Related ticker: (PFE +0.4%)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:14 PM | 7 Comments
  • Y

    Reuters: Alleghany considering sale of TransRe for as much as $6.5B

    • Alleghany (Y +2.5%) pops on a report that the company is considering a sale of its Transatlantic Holdings reinsurance unit in a deal that could value TransRe at ~$6.5B.
    • Alleghany reportedly is working with investment bankers to respond to takeover interest in TransRe from at least one other company, although it has not decided whether to actually sell the business.
    • TransRe was acquired by Alleghany in 2012 for $3.5B.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: PBMD +264%. SRPT +57%. ISR +39%. AVEO +20%. CBAY +19%. DY +19%. OTC:ECTE +19%. MOMO +16%. PBY-OLD +14%. EHIC +14%.
    • Losers: LPTN -80%. ETSY -23%. CISG -22%. OTC:GIGA -19%. REPH -15%. ACHN -15%. MBII -15%. EBIO -15%. SCYX -10%. LEJU -10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • LOV

    Spark Networks up 6.9% on bullish B. Riley coverage

    • B. Riley has launched coverage on Spark Networks (NYSEMKT:LOV) with a Buy rating and $5 target.
    • The launch comes two weeks after the dating site owner plunged in response to a Q1 miss and soft subscriber figures - average paid subs fell 25% Y/Y to 213,445.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:38 PM | 1 Comment
  • AAPL

    Universal Display higher amid Apple speculation

    • Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) will follow up on its use of OLED displays for the Apple Watch by launching iPhones and iPads sporting OLEDs in the 2016/2017 timeframe, argues The Motley Fool's Steve Symington in a column today.
    • Symington notes Apple has reportedly contracted Foxconn and Innolux to build a $2.6B plant to make flexible OLEDs for both smartphones and wearables, and that a JV launched by Japan Display, Sony, and Panasonic (known as JOLED) has reportedly been contracted by Apple to produce OLEDs for next-gen iPads.
    • Universal Display (OLED +2.2%) has made fresh highs, and is now up 89% YTD. Shares jumped two weeks ago after the company disclosed a $45M Q/Q increase in its deferred revenue balance within its Q1 report.
    • Also: LG Display (LPL +0.9%) recently showed off a 55" OLED panel prototype that's only 0.97mm thick - far thinner than its existing 55" panel (4.3mm). The prototype weighs only 1.9kg, and can be stuck to a wall using a magnetic mat.
    • LG, which struck a new licensing deal with Universal earlier this year, says it plans to ramp OLED production in Q3, and is respectively aiming for 2015 and 2016 unit shipments of 600K and 1.5M.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM | 17 Comments
  • GE

    Immelt presents: GE Capital sales ahead of plan

    • Presenting at the Electrical Products Group Conference, General Electric (GE +0.4%) chief Jeff Immelt expects $100B in GE Capital asset sales this year, up from $90B in the previous view. The divestitures should be largely completed by 2016 (the company has previously said all sales should be committed by 2017).
    • Presentation slides and webcast
    • The $35B in dividends to the parent company along with their timing remains on track, as does the plan to apply for SIFI de-designation next year.
    • Confident the Alstom (OTCPK:ALSMY) deal will get approved, GE expects $0.15-$0.20 per share in cost synergies by 2018. Added to that will be $0.35 from the GE Capital and Synchrony exits, plus growth from the industrial businesses.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:15 PM | 8 Comments
  • QIHU

    Qihoo now down 6.5% post-earnings

    • Up moderately in AH trading yesterday after beating Q1 estimates and providing in-line Q2 guidance, Qihoo (NYSE:QIHU) has tumbled towards $55 today.
    • No downgrades have yet arrived. The Q1 slowdown seen in Qihoo's Internet value-added service revenue (up 7.1% Y/Y, after rising 112% in Q4) thanks to PC gaming weakness and online lottery suspensions (offsetting mobile gaming growth) could have some investors on edge.
    • Shares now trade for less than 12x a pre-earnings 2016 EPS consensus of $4.75.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:01 PM | 8 Comments
  • DY

    Dycom +20% as FQ3 tops estimates, FQ4 outlook strong

    • Dycom Industries (DY +20.8%) soars after FQ3 earnings and revenues beat expectations, continuing its streak of higher sales since 2010 and offering upbeat guidance.
    • In February, DY had projected FQ3 EPS to come in below the previous year's $0.28 while revenue was seen at $390M-$415M; the actual results were $0.58 EPS on $492M in revenue.
    • DY's contract revenue for the quarter jumped 48% Y/Y and 6.2% Q/Q to $437.4M, but gross margin narrowed to 3.9% from 4.1% as total costs increased 48%.
    • DY sees FQ4 EPS of $0.74-$0.82 vs. $0.58 analyst consensus estimate and revenues of $550M-$570M vs. $522M consensus.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM
  • AUDC

    AudioCodes up 4% after buyback approved

    • An Israeli court has signed off on AudioCodes' (NASDAQ:AUDC) plans to buy back up to $15M worth of shares (first announced on April 2) by year's end. At current levels, the buyback is good for repurchasing 8% of outstanding shares.
    • AudioCodes spent $5.2M to buy back 1.04M shares in Q1. The company ended Q1 with $84.1M in cash/marketable securities (compares with a current $186.2M market cap), and no debt.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:40 AM
  • PTNR

    Partner Communications -1.3% as Q1 profit falls

    • Partner Communications (NASDAQ:PTNR) is trading down 1.3% after Q1 profits fell 52% Y/Y and missed expectations.
    • Total revenues declined 4% as a slide in service revenues was partly offset by higher equipment sales. Breakouts: Service revenues of NIS 759M ($191M), down 13%; Equipment revenues of NIS 295M ($74M), up 30%.
    • Cost of revenues was also up 2% as gross profit fell 27%.
    • Hot competition in Israel's telecom industry continues taking a toll: The company ended the quarter with 2.77M subscribers, a drop of 162K. Churn was up to 12.7% from Q4's 11.5%. Cellular ARPU was NIS 69, down 3% sequentially.
    • Free cash flow fell 86% to NIS 21M (about $5M), mainly due to increased capex along with EBITDA reduction.
    • Related stocks: Cellcom (NYSE:CEL) down 1.5%; Bezeq (OTCPK:BZQIY) down 0.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:38 AM
  • SGBK

    Cuba reportedly opens bank account at Florida's Stonegate Bank

    • Ft. Lauderdale-based Stonegate Bank (SGBK +3.7%) pops higher as CNBC reports the Cuban government has opened a bank account there.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:34 AM | 2 Comments
  • ADI

    ADI makes new highs after FQ2 beat, strong consumer growth

    • Analog Devices (ADI +3.7%) is adding to its 2015 gains after beating FQ2 estimates with the help of a 40% Y/Y increase in consumer chip sales (13% of revenue). FQ3 guidance is for revenue of $825M-$865M and EPS of $0.71-$0.77, in-line with a consensus of $845.1M and $0.76 and perhaps better than feared given the soft outlooks provided by many peers. 3 firms have hiked their targets.
    • On its CC (transcript), ADI noted "portable applications" lifted consumer sales, and that the segment is also expected to be strong in FQ3. The company landed an Apple Watch touch controller IC design win, and has reportedly scored multiple wins for future iPhones/iPads.
    • ADI (naturally) didn't confirm the iPhone/iPad wins on the call. However, it did predict its consumer ops will "do quite well for the latter half of the year." Consumer gross margins are said to be modestly below the company average.
    • Business performance: Industrial chip sales (48% of revenue, with ADI having a giant share of many market segments) rose 20% Y/Y, telecom chip sales (22% of revenue) 17%, and auto chip sales (17% of revenue) 3%. The Hittite acquisition continues to lift telecom and (to a lesser extent) industrial sales. Like peers, telecom sales have been hurt by weak 4G infrastructure orders.
    • Financials: Gross margin was 66.5%, up 90 bps Q/Q and 40 bps Y/Y, and in-line with guidance. FQ3 GM guidance is at 66%. Operating expenses (non-GAAP) fell to 32.8% of revenue from 34.3% a year ago. $24.3M was spent on buybacks.
    • FQ2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 11:32 AM
  • HIMX

    Himax +5.5%; Rosenblatt upgrades, sees M&A potential for LCoS

    • With shares having closed yesterday just $0.45 above a 52-week low of $5.70, Rosenblatt Securities has upgraded Himax (NASDAQ:HIMX) to Buy, while declaring "the worst is over" for the company and that there's M&A potential for the company's LCoS microdisplay ops.
    • Himax rallied last week after providing mixed Q1 results, soft Q2 guidance, and upbeat commentary about its LCoS efforts, but quickly gave back its gains.
    • After backing out $309M in cash, shares trade for 1x 2015E sales. The 2015 revenue growth consensus is at -4.7%, and the 2016 consensus at 18.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:57 AM | 24 Comments
  • ISR

    Study shows IsoRay's Cesium-131 seeds improve results in lung cancer; shares up 21%

    • Micro cap IsoRay (ISR +21.1%) jumps on an 8x surge in volume in response to its announcement of study results that demonstrated improved outcomes in lung cancer patients treated with its Cesium-131 brachytherapy seeds.
    • Patients with early-stage non-small cell lung cancer who underwent wedge resection (WR) (surgical removal of cancerous cells plus surrounding margin) plus treatment with C-131 (n=52) showed a five-year overall survival (OS) of 100% compared to 97.7% in the WR-only cohort (n=123) and 89.6% in the stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) cohort (n=97).
    • Local control (definition not specified) of the cancer was similar in the three groups: WR - 92.2%; WR+C-131 - 96.2%; SBRT - 95.5%. The differences were not statistically significant (p=0.60).
    • Brachytherapy is a cancer treatment in which radioactive seeds (C-131) are placed in or near the tumor, delivering a high radiation dose to the cancer cells while minimizing the radiation exposure in the surrounding healthy tissues.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:52 AM | 24 Comments

  • ABEO

    PlasmaTech Bio up 9% premarket on FDA designations

    • The FDA designates PlasmaTech Biopharmaceuticals' (PTBI) two gene therapy candidates, MPS IIIB and IIIA, Orphan Drugs for the treatment of Sanfilippo syndromes A and B. The agency also grants Rare Pediatric Disease designations to both.
    • Sanfilippo syndrome is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body is unable to break down long chains of sugar molecules called glycosaminoglycans (mucopolysaccharides). It manifests in young children and is characterized by slow development and behavioral problems and progresses to intellectual decline and motor disease. Life expectancy is only late teens to early twenties. There are no approved therapies for the condition.
    • Orphan Drug status provides for a seven-year period of market exclusivity for the indication, if approved. Rare Pediatric Disease status provides a Pediatric Disease Priority Review Voucher, if approved, that can be used for a future NDA or BLA or can be sold or transferred an unlimited number of times.
    • PTBI is up 9% premarket on robust volume. Shares have been hot of late, more than tripling since the news that hedge fund star George Soros established a stake.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:25 AM

    Yahoo up 2.8% following response to IRS official's remarks

    • A Yahoo (YHOO) statement made via Tumblr: "Yahoo understands that the IRS’s statement is not specific to Yahoo’s planned Q4 2015 spin-off of its remaining stake in Alibaba Group (NYSE:BABA) and Yahoo Small Business, reflects no change in applicable law, and does not affect previously filed ruling requests. Yahoo filed its pending ruling request with the IRS in Q1 2015. Yahoo continues to work toward completing the planned spin-off in Q4 2015."
    • Shares fell 7.6% just before the close yesterday after it was learned IRS senior technician reviewer Isaac Zimbalist had stated the IRS is reviewing rules on "spinoffs of trades or businesses that are small compared with a company’s other assets," and would hold in abeyance new spinoff ruling requests. He added existing applications would still be reviewed, while noting this was subject to change.
    • Zimbalist: "The issue comes down to whether we’ve dropped a hot-dog stand or a lemonade stand into a business that is primarily publicly traded stocks, cash and other wonderful things that I call appreciated property." Yahoo has included its Small Business services unit with the Alibaba spinoff in an attempt to meet the IRS' Active Business requirement. BGC's Colin Gillis notes the IRS' review could also have implications for a potential Yahoo Japan spinoff.
    • Yahoo has rebounded to $42.11 in premarket trading. Alibaba is nearly unchanged.

  • GNCA

    Genocea Bio announces positive data for genital herpes immunotherapeutic candidate GEN-003

    • Thinly traded micro cap Genocea Biosciences (NASDAQ:GNCA) announces positive top-line data from a 310-subject Phase 2 dose optimization study assessing GEN-003 for the treatment of genital herpes. During the 28-day observation period following the completion of dosing, the optimal dose of 60 ug per protein/75 ug of Matrix-M2 adjuvant showed a highly statistically significant 55% reduction from baseline in the viral shedding rate (p<0.0001). All dose combinations demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in viral shedding rate versus baseline.
    • Subjects were randomized in one of six dosing groups (30 ug or 60 ug per protein paired with 25 ug, 50 ug or 75 ug of adjuvant). A seventh group received placebo. Five of the six groups showed a statistically significant reduction in viral shedding rate versus placebo. The lowest dose cohort, 30 ug per protein/25 ug adjuvant, did not.
    • In a secondary analysis based on patient-reported genital lesion rates, all dose groups, including placebo, showed a statistically significant reduction from baseline.
    • GEN-003 contains pieces of the herpes virus that is designed, along with an adjuvant, to boost the immune system to fight genital herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2).
    • The company will host a conference call this morning at 9:00 am ET to discuss the results.
    • Shares are up 29% premarket on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:53 AM
